job_title: Chief Nursing Officer in San Antonio, TX
pros: Supportive company, flexible schedule, employee recognition.
cons: I would not have any cons as of yet.

review_title: No culture, no work life balance, poor management.
pros: None the place is a mess! However reading more of these reviews from others a lot more makes sense as to why the company is awful.
cons: Work life balance is non existent. Management expects navigators or anyone really to work 24/7 and will text you at all hours expecting a reply. Regional Corporate DSI regularly talks about doing  illicit  activities in front of employees and is extremely unprofessional.  CEO is extremely unprofessional and childish, will engage in drama and rumors and allow them to continue without doing anything. Nothing is ever told to HR without being told to the entire staff or having repercussions.  People are placed into management positions without ever having management experience. The president of the company preaches equality and culture and that is completely non-existent. ODH frequently visits the LTAC due to complaints, poor staffing and poor patient care. The staffing for nursing and RT is horrific and extremely unsafe. I would never send my family member there. Just check the google reviews from patients and families. A lot of the positive ones are from employees who’ve been told to place them. Bonuses are never paid on time and are 6 months late if you ever get them. They will make multiple excuses not to pay a bonus when it is due as well.

job_title: Physical Therapist in Round Rock, TX
pros: 1:1 therapist to patient care. No group therapy. Food service is now up to par. Get an annual plain t-shirt from corporate for employee appreciation.
cons: Benefits are sub par. 401k contribution is only up to 1% Pay is lowest in the area; corporate controls rates and doesn't do market analysis. Raises are minimal. Rarely pay overtime; no bonuses for therapists. 8:1 patient to nurse ratio for nursing care for LVNs, and 16:1 for CNAs. Charge nurse constantly over worked. Night shift nursing has always been a joke and management doesn't change it. They talk a lot about doing employee engagement and appreciation events, but do a poor job with follow through. Declined to even give an employee a free cafeteria lunch during/for employee annual review. They take whatever patients pay the most. Patients and family rarely have much input in discharge plans and PMR& Case management update family's very late. CEO and corporate only focus on the management up revenue for corporate; very little revenue is put back into the building or staff. Air conditioning breaks literally 5 times a year and corporate only approves "bandage fixes". Heat can not keep up with winter weather; patient rooms will be 60-65 degrees when temperate outside near 30degrees. All non-clinical jobs well under paid; you will make more at Pizza hut.

review_title: No true leadership & not Culture driven
pros: I am not able to come up with any.
cons: Leadership is non existent . You get minimal training and preparation for presentations, meetings , system training, etc. everything is a “fire” in the revenue cycle office. If you ask questions or offer recommendations to possibly streamline process or ask to take time to actually look into an issue rather than “react” you are told you are not moving fast enough and you are told they have “lost faith!” How can you lose faith when you’ve never taken the time to allow your managers to truly work with their team or build communication within their own teams. Although you choose and hire your managers, once we are in, you express zero faith in our directives and do not allow any ideas or implementation ideas at all without making us feel “less than.” I am a thriving manager & thriving in my current role yet at PAM and under William I was questioning everything.

pros: Tons of flexibility Good pay
cons: High turnover on management in some areas

job_title: Registered Nurse in Las Vegas, NV

cons: High turnover, especially in leadership.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sugar Land, TX
pros: Leadership cares about me Reasonable pay Good training period
cons: No 401K match Expensive benefits

pros: I left the company like most because of William and Shirley like most do!!!
cons: They don’t care for their employees, or how many hours you work. William and Shirley are the worse, they brought their people in that didn’t know anything and moved them up the ladder pretty quick. If you don’t do what they tell you to do they will find a way to get rid of you. You would think by now that Tony would get rid of William and his people since the turnover is so high on a daily. Like William would say if you ever get hit by a train we need to know what you do.

review_title: Would never step foot in this facility again. Beware.
pros: Had a great team of nurses that worked together for years with awesome physical therapists and occupational therapist.
cons: Worked here for a number of years. New CEO came in that was a physical therapist who didn’t have a clue about nursing. He was admitting patients who had no business at the facility on top of making the workload 8:1 ratio with 1 aide most of the time for all patients. New computer system was suppose to be better charting and made more mistakes with no accountability if you scanned a narcotic and had 2, you only needed to scan one. The company just cares about a warm body.

pros: They are a growing company, with a lot of opportunity. They do value promoting from within
cons: EMR is cumbersome and requires repetitive documentation. A lot of micromanagement from corporate level

pros: I can’t think of any
cons: Extremely unsafe patient assignments, leadership that doesn’t listen, bonuses are not paid, short staffed everyday, TERRIBLE director of nursing

pros: I had a great team
cons: Poor leadership Leadership are bullies and have no backbone, no empathy or emotion intelliegence HR is a joke, there is no confidentiality he will run a tell everything to the VP There will be retaliation if you complain or voice your opinion (I was let go because of it) The VP has no respect for his director, managers and their employees. Pay is poor for the amount of work there and the micro management if out of control.

pros: No pros at all here.
cons: Bad management, no adequate training for the new employees, worst place for nurses, dangerous environment. Overall, I would say to new nurses that please save your license by not applying here.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Sugar Land, TX
pros: Small hospital family appeal. Good management.
cons: EMR not friendly and constant internet and plumbing issues

review_title: Use your skills and make a difference
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Fargo, ND
pros: I worked for PAM for roughly 9 months before moving from the area. It was a good experience as an LPN to care for post acute care rehab patients; use your skills for IVs (need IV certification), catheters, dressing changes and managing patients.
cons: Often worked short staffed and had up to 8-9 patients instead of the standard 6, usually on multiple wings. This was troublesome when you had more time consuming tasks with the patients and also had high fall risk patients further apart. Charting system Wellsky is redundant and not efficient at all. A daily assessment took a long time to complete and times that by 6-9 patients, stayed late often to complete charting. Management often not on the floor to help when it is chaotic and short staffed. Says they are a “pamily” but felt more like you were alone and not supported when you brought concerns or suggestions up. Some coworkers were less than team players, which happens everywhere. 1 CNA for 12-18 patients typically. This is troublesome when you are short staffed, pressure sensor pads are alarming, call lights going off and cares needing done between therapy sessions. Weekend staffing was awful. Minimal to no therapy on weekends, nursing/cna typically short and if the schedule was “full” would often have call outs or no shows on the weekend, especially Sunday. Kept advocating for better weekend staffing as therapy plays a huge role during the week in getting patients up and moving, extra hands to help with walks and toileting. I know other staff, patients and family members felt like the weekend was a mess due to this as well.

pros: Low expectations, unrealistic quota. Don’t expect to receive bonus, so not reaching the goal isn’t an issue.
cons: Too many hands on the pot, lack of leadership, lots of drama.

job_title: EVS Tech in San Antonio, TX
pros: Easy job to work at
cons: Lot of work done over and over again

pros: Great money during COVID. My department was ran so smoothly, I have nothing but positive things to say about our team. The three of us worked very well together during my time in purchasing and inventory at PAM

pros: Enjoyed my coworkers, however high turnover

review_title: If chaos is your thing, come on in!
pros: Not really any, it's a pretty miserable space.
cons: The employees are so miserable resulting in short tempers, unprofessional attitudes, and lack of respect for other departments. Never ending finger pointing and they are the BEST at using fear and intimidation to force you into doing something. The CEO is ridiculously unprofessional and will fire someone at the drop of a hat. He curses frequently, has literally negative amount of clinical knowledge and doesn't understand what any of the floor staff actually do. They are great at rewarding the staff who do a poor job and don't show up instead of focusing on their hardworking staff that do.

pros: Great teamwork, no cliques within the therapy department, good working relationship amongst the departments.
cons: Occasional rift between some departments, mainly therapy and nursing, but unfortunately that’s everywhere.

pros: Not really any pros to working here.
cons: My coworkers on the floor are great/look out for each other. Administration people seem kind of unhappy and should realize their attitude trickles down. LOTS of nepotism especially from the HR department so be careful who you talk to. The older human resource lady seems lacking in knowledge and a work place bully. I’ve personally witnessed her on more than one occasion be mean to some of my sweet coworkers for no reason. I’m just here for some experience and will move on as soon as my prn job has a full time opening.

review_title: Joke of a place for employees and patients alike
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Jacksonville, FL
pros: No drug test so I guess that’s a pro if you use illegal drugs. Fast hire process because they’re desperate for people. Minimal supervision.
cons: Patients have no dignity, lay in their filth, hear employees cursing in the halls, patients leave worse than they came or they die in the facility. Very poor management. I’ve seen 4 employees quit with only a moments notice in the last two weeks. I’ll be quitting next week. Employees practice outside their scopes of practice. No useful hands on training, just thrown out onto the floor to work unsupervised. No accountability and drug errors amongst nurses not being documented. Unorganized needs a bigger word to describe this location. I wouldn’t even send my pet here to be treated much less a spouse or other family member.

Money is important, but people are the most important.

job_title: Charge Nurse in Rocky Mount, NC
pros: great coworkers, good teamwork. Patients were able to make a lot of progress
cons: Terrible administration, no support, overworked, short staffed. CEO kept sending emails basically directing us to treat the worker's comp patients better than others. We had to move patients out of the rooms they'd been in for weeks in order to give these patients the biggest rooms. Asking us to staff a worker's comp patient 1:1 despite the fact we barely had enough staff to take care of the other patients. Administration and corporate would not listen when they were asked to hold admissions to give their overworked staff a break.

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Round Rock, TX
pros: The staff is friendly and most everyone tries to help each other. The nursing staff and therapy staff work well together and communication is good. Charge nurses are helpful when you need them. The average patient ratio is 1:7 and ranges from 6-8. Pay is good.
cons: Equipment and supplies are frequently lacking or broken. Not enough vital sign machines, not enough working mobile computers/nurse carts, supply room frequently out of materials on the weekends b/c of no supply staff, a small med-dispense system so you waste a LOT of time standing in line at two different systems to get your patients morning medications. The Charting system is crazy slow and a repetitive documentation time suck.

pros: Pay for work is ok
cons: Bad policies, bad corporate leadership, bad working environment, just bad

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Lufkin, TX
pros: Complexity of Patients, HR Manager is a problem solver.
cons: Patient care suffers here, DRASTICALLY. Nurses frequently assigned 4-6 critical care (total care) patients, sometimes on opposite ends of the unit, usually COVID +, with 3-8 drips between them, blood administration (you must leave the floor to obtain), All too large to turn alone with the vents, trachs, and lines, with no-one else available to assist because all nurses were staffed similarly and the unit sec. is either sleeping, off the floor for a smoke break, or not otherwise available, and the RT has their hands full with nebs. There was a tech scheduled but she was cancelled (after she drove an hour to get to work). Additionally the RN was responsible for obtaining daily blood / lab draws, paper charting, assembling paper charts and MAR's for the next day, performing chart reviews, updating care plans, family / physician communication, and so much more. DO NOT BE SUCKERED by their large bonuses (there's a reason they offer bonuses...you usually have to pay it back). There have been approx. 15 high quality, experienced, RN's and LVN's that have quit there over the past 8 months (as of Mar 2021). And so many patients are dying (preventably) because of lack of quality care and the RN's inability to properly react to critical information in a timely manner.

job_title: Rehabilitation Technician in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-Great teamwork and effort across multidisciplinary teams.
-Staff appreciation events in hopes to boost moral
-Excellent response time to emergency situations.
-High quality of knowledge across departments.
-Great weekly interdisciplinary patient care meetings to provide updates on current patients' statuses.
cons:
-Executive management was noncompliant with lower waged staff's concerns or complaints.
-Pressure from higher waged staff to maintain/discharge patients above the patient's best plan of care to meet profitable numbers.
-Overworked, understaffed, and underpaid departments resulting in deminished quality of patient care.
-Frequent policy changes with ineffective forms of communication to transfer information to all departments.
-Security was "let go" and there is no longer anyone to keep the staff members safe between shifts and at nighttime.
-High turnover with little to no chance of a promotion from within.

pros: Team Support. PRN pay was above average. Pay differential increased on the weekend. Easy to arrange for time off. The therapy gym was well equipped. cons: Full-time pay and benefits weren't as great as most other rehab hospitals. DOR at the time wasn't very helpful or accessible. Would double up patient loads per therapist at times when fully populated. Started cutting back on costs which was passed onto the employees. Sometimes set goals too high for more debilitated patients.

pros: Colleagues, both in nursing and therapy, were hard working and caring individuals who did what they could within the confines of what management allowed and provided. Many went above and beyond and regularly worked several hours a day off of the clock. Patients were always wonderful to work with, despite increasing acuity levels.
cons: It is exceedingly sad when you and your coworkers all agree that were your own family or friends to need medical care and rehab, you would not allow them to go to your own work. Patients lack basic care due to understaffing and the lack of willingness to spend on basic equipment and supplies for patients by management. Compensation is not commensurate with industry standards with PAM paying substantially less than other area hospitals. Pressure is placed on all staff to work off the clock to meet productivity standards that are not realistic. Morale is low and therapists and nurses have a high-rate of turn-over due to working conditions. Management is uncaring and places blame on staff, even when asked for help and issues pointed out repeatedly. I cannot in good conscience recommend this company to any one I know, neither as a place to work nor as a place to receive care.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Greenfield, WI
pros: co-workers, compensation is fair, scheduler is very accommodating
cons: Very high rate of employee turn over. 4 directors of nurses, 2 nurse managers, 3 CEO's, 2 Human resource representatives, 2 maintenance managers, 2 dietary managers  and many very competent nursing staff, all terminated and walked out of the hospital in the 1.5 yrs. while  I was employed here. Myself, I had never been written up or called into human resources. 3 weeks ago I was called in to human resources and told that I was being terminated because some staff complained about how I spoke to them. There was no progressive discipline, and I was not told anything further, and they didn't want to hear anything I had to say. I have a previous 12 year history of being employed with the same employer in an inpatient mental health setting, prior to being employed here. My previous employer had about 4 in-services a year related to communication, and I had never been talked to about my communication skills at my previous employment. Administration does not adhere to their own policies and procedures. The leadership at this local hospital is very chaotic, and your never sure who is in charge. Nepotism is very much a part of the environment with this employer This employer is hanging on by a thread.

pros: Administration only concerned about their bonuses. The State needs to shut this place down - patients sit in their feces for hours due to staffing shortages. Mass exodus of employees due to poor mgmt.
cons: Reiterating because this is so true at the Milwaukee location - Corporate is completely out of their element. They are a rehab company trying to run LTACHs. The corporate and facility level management does not provide any level of support to the staff and is quick to place blame on anybody but themselves when they don't get results on paper that they want. There is constant lip service given to what is wrong, but management does not have the experience or ability to actually work forward on solutions. Their efforts are spent on justifying why any issues are not their fault but rather the fault of their predecessor or other departments. Most of the staff can easily see that management is not there to support and is concerned only with their own reputations and bonuses. This is not a new problem and shows no signs of changing any time soon.

review_title: This Place is Horrible  (All Smoke and Mirrors)
pros: Decent Benefits, Good Supplies, even a few well trained nurses.
cons: Nurse Management is the Worst!  Continue to add more and more paperwork but show little regard for patient care.  Staff morale the worst it's ever been compliments to the front office bullies. Virtually NO nursing Training or Teaching here; just threats when something you were never taught isn't done. Deplorable Staffing ratios, frequently get called off, hard to get a FT pay check at a FT job. If you work an extra shift for them you'll just get called off later in the week.  Your CNA staff frequently called off or sent home 1/2 shift so you can be expected to do Hi-Acuity total patient care (5-6 patients) without any backup. And guaranteed to be threatened with your job if you forget 1 thing on an extremely busy night.

review_title: Extremely great therapists to work alongside at Warm Springs Westover Hills outpatient department. Poor management.
pros: Good team work and work family at Warm Springs Westover hills outpatient clinic.
cons: Corporate company focused on making money & has poor communication with their employees. However the corporate staff does not have experience with running an outpatient clinic ( post acute is mainly and acute inpatient hospital) and has unrealistic expectations for their therapists. All therapists seem to have burn-out with the only thing holding us together are each other and our love for the job.

review_title: The Worst Job I've Ever Had
pros: The frontline staff really care about the patients.  We had a good CNO (note I said HAD).
cons: Benefits are overpriced and under-serving. Corporate employees feed the frontline staff garbage when they come to visit. CEO at our facility is way to inexperienced. They allowed our CNO to resign without even trying to keep her, best one we have had in the 15 years this building has been open.

review_title: Difficult Leadership, Patient care is NOT the priority.
pros: Pay was decent, and once upon a time, it was a great hospital with good patient care and happy employees. Good insurance.
cons:
The hospital used to be great a while back. When leadership changed again, those who took over were looking at numbers only, and didn't take the time to learn the people. The new leadership assumed that the problem was too much spending and decided to eliminate support positions and increase nursing and therapy ratios in patient care. They did nothing to keep the staff calm, and tons of people left...
With tons more looking to leave. Nothing like being afraid for your job because there are no patients in the building, and it's not a new thing.

review_title: As in life...work is what you make it
job_title: Director of Quality Management/Risk Assurance in Hammond, LA
pros: Endless opportunities if your willing to do the work.  Team orientated work atmosphere. Corporate actually listens and responds accordingly.  Corporate allows facilities to grow and develop their teams accordingly.  Corporate intervenes at the facility level only when the facility isn’t performing as expected. The benefit packages are the best I’ve ever had working in hospitals.  Day to day success depends how well you work with your team within your facility. Everyone has a job to do and a performance expectation to uphold.  It’s amazing how many positive things happen when people just do their job.
cons: My personal preference would include a more competitive salary that is comparable to the current regional or national average for my job position and/or responsibilities.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Milwaukee, WI
pros: THE PEOPLE WHO WORK ON THE FLOOR ARE AMAZING!!! I cannot stress how nice the staff is to each other and how well they work as a team.
cons: paper charting, old equipment, no phones for the staff only walkie talkies. the doctors cannot get a hold of the nurses if they call in. Charting and order writing is VERY redundant and wastes a lot of valuable time. The med room and the process they have in place to obtain meds is a complete waste of time.

pros: The pay is okay but not that competitive with larger territories.  Some places are nice but still short of nurses.
cons:
This place is MICRO-MANAGED  all the way to the top.
Never seen anything like it.  All corporate admin are micro-managing emails.  They don’t care about how many hours you put in a day or how much work is piled on you.  This is the hardest place you’ll ever work at... No Corp credit cards- you pay and expense it all with ongoing marketing events. You have homework every night and more.  If this is how you want to work, this is the place.  No one listens to your concerns, forget it.
They are the typical Corp. BULLIES.....

pros: Great benefits, hands on training, very competitive pay rates and the people and leadership are amazing! The corporate culture is relaxed while there is a major feeling of being a part of a team.  Expectations and goals are high but the support is present to help all employees achieve set goals. Senior leadership is very visible and involved in day to day business.
cons: As with all great organizations, the pace of work is relentless. No coasting at this company though the people there aren't the type to ease off. If you're not willing or able to work at a high level look elsewhere.

pros: Twelve hr shifts are good
cons: Everything!  Rude non caring management, no staff, high turnover rates-now to the point they can't hire anyone.  No patients because physicians don't want to send their patients over.  Have to borrow supplies from Main host hospital or rig stuff up because of no supplies.  Management has left Knowing there are only 2 RN's on with 17 patients while they are Rn's & can help cover.  Have been in workforce for 33yrs & this is the all time worst place! Being flexed off all the time, haven't had a full paycheck in months with no vacation time to use. I can keep going on all day, PLEASE it's just bad from management on up!

review_title: Run, run as fast as you can!!
pros:
Clean facility
New Hospital
Patients like the food
cons:
Worse job experience I have ever had 
Horrible culture
Cut Throat
Finance comes first, before patient care or human capital
Employees  are not valued; completely disposable
No support from upper management
Unprofessional and negative  upper management
You will not be given the tools you need
You will not be given the training you need
You will not be given the personnel you need
You will be expected to perform, financially, within your first week, no matter the current condition of your department; if not, you can wave good-bye.

pros: Post Acute Medical is a great company to work for with a lot of opportunity for growth and advancement.  It is exciting to be part of a company that is growing so quickly and feels really good to work for someone that genuinely cares about their employees and values their opinions.
cons: With as quickly as we are growing communication may sometimes seem unclear, but those that take the time to ask will come to realize that decisions are made with everyone's best interest in mind.

pros: Oh ok let me think hmm.. The elevators work !
cons: It’s very old fashioned  the patients have tubes TVs in their rooms dated equipment ,Poor Management , Unorganized  no leadership unsafe work environment, They assign one aide to 14 patients no team work the nurses are lazy they treat staff unfairly! They only care about keeping the beds filled and making money off of the patients ! It’s basically a nursing home .They cancel constantly back to back ,So don’t expect a full pay check!!! This is the Greenfield,Wi Location by the way !! I Wouldn’t recommend this place to any patient let alone a new potential employee ! It’s a crap shack  ! And needs to be shut down immediately!!!!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Overland Park, KS
pros:
New building, great team and access to new equipment. High PRN rate, typical (slightly sub standard though) benefits. Good focus on getting clinical staff extra educational funds/ CEUs. Low rehab staff turnover. Few weekends required of full time staff compared to other facilities in the city.  Great PRN job if you are willing to work weekends and odd hours, both nursing and rehab wise. Be ready to have a call last minute- either to work or to be cancelled. (see Cons and advice). Middle management and DOR really care about staff and are trying their best to balance corp and staff needs. Very approachable from my experience. 

As far as a rehab staff members small day-to-day bubble you will get a fair pay, a great set of workers and generally speaking wonderful patients. You'll work in a pretty new building. There are a lot of big, over-head issues...but doesn't every system have them? They don't USUALLY directly affect you though.
cons: High CEO/Admin turn over, little actual help from corporate other then occasional drop in's to try and switch entire processes up. Typical new hospital start up issues: nursing/admin staff turnover, issues stabilizing census. Lots and Lots of effort and changes to processes that were not really the main concern or issue. PAPER DOCUMENTATION

pros: The staff at post acute medical are extremely warm and out going. Clearly they care a lot for the company they work with and for, as well as the patients that serve. It is an honor to be able to work for this company, and serve these patients. Post Acute Medical of Milwaukee has a great care team that will go the extra mile for patient comfort and satisfaction.
cons: The building is a bit older and some of the décor could be updated.

job_title: RN Clinical Navigator in Sarasota, FL
pros: Kind and friendly group of people to work with in Sarasota.  Managers are all experienced and professional. Nursing staff is seasoned and treat every patient with respect.
cons: PAM specializes in Inpatient Acute Rehab Hospitals. Long Term Acute Care Hospital is a secondary business. You cannot run both types of hospital with the same lens. As with many bonus incentive plans, they have structured their bonus structure to make it nearly impossible to reach goals and earn extra money. Bonus is calculated after all income and expenses.

review_title: THE T E XARKANA SOUTH LOCATION SUCKS
pros: The only pro is that you may get paid 10.00 an hour
cons: There is no team work management sucks hey spread lots of rumors this company changed names it should have got new management and employees you do not want to work for this company period no working for this company will stress you out the nurses don't care about the patients they sit on their butts doing nothing while the CNAS get the scrap worked out of them they look for you for 15 to 20 minutes to do something they could have done themselves I don't see this company staying in business much longer because of management lazy good for nothing charge nurses and nurses

pros: Benefits, PTO, schedule flexibility in certain circumstances
cons: The company grew and expanded at a rate too fast for its support staff to keep pace; IT support to sites plummeted in 2014 and has not improved

pros: Overall, there are nice people there.
cons: It's hard to know where to start. The corporate team is a joke. They lack strategy, vision and integrity.  They walk around with chests puffed up saying I'm corporate. They, however, do not invest in infrastructure, do not allow autonomy and insult people. My second week the COO called a CNS 'ghettoish' and the regional VP called women sweetheart all the time. Yes, the pay is good, but it has to be. It was worth it to make significantly less money to leave.

job_title: Corporate Helpdesk Coordinator in Enola, PA
pros:
Become part of a team where everyone is a valued member. Your knowledge and experience will not only be recognized, but appreciated. Senior management is very understanding and workable.

Employment in the Post Acute Medical IT department will challenge you in new ways almost every day. Their diverse environment brings an interesting mix of technologies to the table. Learning opportunities abound.

This is an amazing opportunity to become part of a company that is growing by the day.

Great PTO and benefits.

Military friendly workplace.
cons: Due to the rapid growth and expansion of Post Acute Medical, the IT department is somewhat short staffed at the moment.

pros: I love the interaction with the corporate team.  Front line staff is never made to feel intimidated. The pay scale is competitive.
cons: Difficult to staff quality critical care nurses.   Does not provide payroll deduction for scrubs.

review_title: Enjoy the local people, hate the corporation
pros: Enjoy the people I see and work with on a daily basis. Enjoy my job.
cons: Corporate management (from afar) brings down the local moral. Only care about $$ and heads in the bed (but also appear to not be able to figure how $$ and heads in the bed don’t always equate out). Census and operations are NEVER good enough, they will find something to harass and rip those directors apart for. When they visit, they don’t actually assist or do anything productive, except sit on conference calls. If you are here for support, then get in the trenches and support. Corporate constantly puts departments against each other, but then want team work out of the conflict CORPORATE  creates. Corporate beats up, harasses, and makes local their directors feel like pieces of worthless crap (which would explain the turnover for almost all director titles every 3-6 months).  Don’t worry! If you are hired, they will tell you that the negative posts are all results of previous disgruntled employees. Don’t forget that when you go home at night, you will have plenty of items to do in order to stay on top of your job duties, as they also expect highly unrealistic amounts of work out of individuals. There is not enough time in the day. (But if that is stated, you will be told you are clearly not efficient or using your time wisely). You are expected to work far more and harder than what your salary is worth.

pros: Coworkers and the patients were the only things that made this job tolerable
cons:
•Management 
•Favoritism 
•Paper charting
•old equipment 
•Unorganized in all aspects
•One lazy supervisor who doesn’t do a thing and the another who micromanages everything
•CNO has no experience and no idea what she is doing.  Posts inappropriate things regarding work to Facebook.  Ignored the fact a RN was diverting narcotics for months
•Asks nurses to cover shifts to the point of allowing them to work 20hr days
•unsafe patient ratios
•no communication between staff
•bullying 
•inappropriate staff relationships
•retaliation from management 
•no one is held accountable for their actions

pros: Post Acute Medical is one of the best healthcare companies I have ever worked for! Management team is great and the corporate office is easy to talk to.
cons: The IT department was a bit hard to get ahold of, but has made major changes in the last year, and is much easier to speak to now.

job_title: Director of Plant Operations in Milwaukee, WI
pros: A great company to work for.  Post Acute Medical views employee growth as something very important.  Employee accountability and ownership of assignments are also promoted though out all disciplines.
cons: I truly have nothing bad to say about Post Acute Medical. My time as a Post Acute Medical employee has been a wonderful opportunity.

pros: Availability for overtime and great coworkers.
cons: Everything else. Management works us to the bone with max patients. Almost everyday we are short of staff and the management nitpicks on the smallest things. Our facility was bought out by PAM and they changed everything for the worse. Benefits that barely cover anything, cutting corners with supplies and staffing. I wouldn't recommend anyone work here ever.

pros: There is nothing good about this company...RUN!!
cons: I’d give this company zero stars if I could. This company is all about the bottom dollar and not the employee. The CEO, Claudia Hauser, is completely delusional and doesn’t want people who actually understand CMS guidelines. She wants “yes men” puppets who will do what she says, whether it’s fraudulent or not.

pros: Good wage, good benefits, corporate office is in touch with what is going on in the respective facility, Corporate CEO stresses the importance of work and personal life
cons: Reimbursements for expense reports sometimes take up to 2 months to be processed and mailed

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Tulsa, OK
pros: There is good Teamwork. Great charge nurses, and scheduling works with my school schedules. Good attitudes out on the floor for the most part. Great doctors work with us as well.
cons: Occasional low census with results in canceled shifts. That isn’t to bad if you have PTO to cover. If you take vacation sometimes sometimes you don’t.

review_title: Rehab facility need for staff improvements not more material improvements as evidenced by high turn over
pros:
coworkers become family
Competative pay
promotions from within
cons:
unappreciative toward staff ESPECIALLY nursing
12 hour shifts
recent insurance changes

job_title: Senior Project Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Fair Pay and good training. Will be treated well on local levels
cons: High Demands 24/7 if you are management. Corporate level will treat all others very poorly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Milwaukee, WI
pros: Co-workers Nurses, and CNA's are a team, they are tough and willing to help. Great people!
cons: No training, unobtainable expectations, unsafe for patients and employees due to lack of training and support.  No support from administration. There is a reason most of administration have not been there for more than a year and the CNO they have currently has no skills, management support or idea what to do.

job_title: Occupational Therapist in San Antonio, TX
pros: None that i can think of to list.
cons: Productivity is pushed so much that it is strongly encouraged for therapists to complete their paperwork off the clock as overtime is strongly discouraged.

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in Greenfield, WI
pros: Fair wages & benefits for the position. Cafeteria open for lunch on day shift. Employee S are very hard working.
cons: Not enough staff for patient load. Still using paper medical charts very little on computer. Difficult to do care tracking.

pros:

pros: If you work hard and don’t have many ethics and willing to backstab your coworkers you’ll get ahead and make good money. Great benefits.

pros: Environment and coworkers, make this job special

pros: I personally had a great experience with a great boss. Really high pay.

review_title: How can u have love for patients when u don't care about your employees
